description: From Middle English port-reve etc., from Old English portgerēfa etc., from port (“a walled market town”) +‎ gerēfa (“reeve”).

entries.meaning: A borough-reeve: an office equivalent to a mayor (historical) in several major English towns or (dialect) in various minor boroughs of Wales and Southwest England.
examples: Instead of the portgreve [of London], Richard the first ordained two bailiffs, but presently after him King John granted them a mayor for their yearly magistrate.

entries.meaning: (historical) A municipal office subordinate to a mayor, (especially) a bailiff.
(historical) A port reeve, a port warden.
